segments.text: Angela Caso, C-A-S-S-O.
C-A-S-S-O.
Apparently it sounds like an Italian name, but it seems like generations back it was spelled C-A-Z-O.
Why and who changed it, we don't know.
But now the whole family is C-A-S-S-O.
And I was born in Revolaredo.
So was my sister.
So was my mother.
And my father was born in the state of Coahuila.
But they moved.
I really don't know how young he was when they moved to Nuevo Laredo.
And he and my mother were married when she was only 16 years old.
She was just a child, so to speak.
And there were only two of us, my sister, who is four years older than myself, and I.
Unfortunately, we lost mother when I was just a very, very young baby.
And even though my father was very young, he did not remarry until after we were married and after I had children.
So, as a consequence, he moved in, or rather, my grandmother, my father's mother, was a widow.
And she had to...

daughters and married daughters, and one of his sisters, his oldest sister, was the one who raised me, who raised us, but I think of her just like my mother because she actually took care of me since I was five months old.
I don't stop to realize that I'm sure my grandmother had a lot to do with it.
Was your grandmother living with you too?
Yes, in other words, my father, when mother died,
my father moved in with his family.
Or rather, he made a home for his family.
He was always supporting my widowed grandmother and his two sisters, young sisters.
And so from there on, of course, there were different moves because my father was a customs man.
He worked for customs.
He had an important position.
And we lived for a while, we lived in what is now, well, in Piedras Negras.
In those days it was called Porfirio Diaz.
Yes, this was before 1910.
Yes.
But I don't remember except that my mother, the one who raised me, married at the time.
In Piedras Negras.

in what did she marry in oh wow she married a man from this side from from the northern side so uh my father in the meantime had been transferred to piedras negras and he took his family my grandmother his two sisters my sister and myself but that night i started crying and crying and crying i wanted mama i wanted mom so um he wired because i guess in those days wiring a sending telegram was
Are you comfortable there, Miss Catherine?
Would you like to sit on one of these rockers?
You try.
It's part of the family's old furniture, too.
So anyway, my mother and her husband moved to Piedras Negras because of me.
But that's when the revolution started, as far as I really don't know.
How old were you when it began?
But let's see, I guess I was three years old.
Then we moved back to Nuevo Laredo.
When, I don't know.
I really don't know.
About our moving to this side when we actually became refugees, I remember some, just vaguely,
I do remember, we lived right in the heart of what is now Nueva Laredo.
Have you been across?
Have you been to Mexico?
All right.
The first little plaza, let's see, one, two blocks west.
That was where our home was.
And I don't remember, it's funny, but I just don't remember what the house was like.
I know it was a brick house.
I don't remember what furniture was in it.
I don't remember anything except one thing, this picture.
That's the only thing that I remember of my early, early childhood days.
It's a beautiful picture.
It's a beautiful picture, and it was a picture on her namesake.
She was my father's youngest sister, and she died when she was 90 years old, so he named me after her.
And I remember that- Angelina.
Angela.
Angela.
A-N-G-L-A, Angela.
And of course, she was Angela Caso, C-A-S-S-O, the same as my name, my maiden name.
So anyway, that's the only thing that I remember, that, and I always had a dog.
What kind of dog?
Just a plain old dog.
Just any dog.
As long as it was a dog.
Ordinary dog.
Ordinary dog would do for me.
And of course my dolls and things like that.
And my father was a very, very, he was not with the revolutionists at all.
He belonged to the old
party, so to speak.
He had been a government employee with customs under the administration.
I mean, he was still, he was a porfirista all the time.
In fact, they used to say that when they asked me as a young child, no, I would make this question.
It's very, very childish, but I would always ask the questions, what are you?
Carrancista or porfirista?
No.
Maderista or Porfirista?
Because there was Madero and there was Porfirio.
Catlica o protestante?
Catholic or Protestant?
It seemed like they, as far as I was concerned, they had to be Catholics.
Rich or poor?
And we weren't rich.
We were Catholics, yes, but we weren't rich.
But yet I wanted those three qualities.
Just like a child, I guess.
So anyway, I never attended school in Mexico.
Do you remember what year your family moved across the border?
Sister says that we moved in 1912.
So this would have been after Diaz was overthrown and Madero had become president.
Yes, but I think that it was
The revolution was between Huerta.
And the Carrancistas.
And the Carrancistas.
And Huerta, of course, by that time represented the federal government again.
Yes, yes.
So my aunt, the one who raised me, lived on this side.
I remember that many times, I couldn't tell you how many times, but I do remember that during the night they would wake us up
and we would have to walk across because there was the alarm that the Revolucionistas were coming.
So half asleep and just they practically dragged us.
Of course as I say it was right in town and we didn't have a car and very few people did.
So we would cross the bridge and get to Mother's.
She lived
where Crestor is now located, which is in the very heart of town.
And of course, we would come and stay with her.
Then it would quiet down.
My father would say, all right, everything is all right.
It was just a false alarm, so we would get back across.
How many times we did that, I don't know.
But when the real thing happened, we had already crossed.
My grandmother.
one of my aunts, my sister, and myself.
My father didn't come with us because he joined the federal government.
And he was...
He joined the military?
Well, in other words, I guess he wanted to help.
And he had been sent the paycheck, the payroll, for all of the custom men.
And he felt like he had to find them and pay each one what was due to him.
And so we came, and I do remember that my grandmother used to cry quite often because she hadn't heard from Daddy, of course.
I wasn't aware of the fact that Daddy was in danger.
Then there's another very, how shall I put it, very much alive thing in my mind.
And that was when they burned Nuevo Laredes.
They set fire to Nuevo Laredes.
And we could see the flames and the smoke and everything.
And my grandmother was crying.
She says, there goes my home.
And of course, I mean, I guess they say that my grandmother was just thinking that it was her home.
It did go down in fire.
I mean, it was destroyed.
As most of the city was.
It was not a big city, but anyway, everything.
And the only thing, I don't believe that we brought any clothes with us.
I really don't believe we did.
The only thing that my grandmother made sure that was crossed at the very first time was this picture.
She brought it and left it here for safekeeping.
So you had left and come over here, but you hadn't brought that much with you.
Perhaps they were planning to go back?
Yes, I'm sure that my father was very optimistic.
He couldn't believe that the government would be...
output by the revolution.
I don't think anyone ever believed it was going to last so long.
He didn't believe, he didn't want to accept the fact that unfortunately that was what was happening.
Unfortunately for them, but fortunately for many others.
So I don't know how many hours or how many what the fire lasted.
I couldn't tell you because I'm sure that it was extinguished to the best of their abilities.
whichever way they were able to do it.
But I remember that after it was all over, crossing the bridge was no problem.
It was just like going down the street.
There was no immigration department to ask you where you were born.
There was no registration at all on either side?
Nothing whatsoever.
And my grandmother went across the river and she came back and she said that she had, as a young,
Her family was a family of means.
My great-grandfather was a wealthy man, and his children naturally, in those days, they thought that the boys were the ones who were supposed to keep most everything, not the girls.
But she did have some things like silver pieces.
She didn't bring any of them.
And they were all lost in the family?
They were all lost.
The only thing she found was all the silver melted.
But of course there was a lot of robbery around.
I mean, it was in the hands of...
In fact, I don't even know who was responsible.
They even say, my husband, if you would ask my husband, he would say that it was the same general who was with the government that set fire to the Nuevo Laredo
rather than have it fall in the hands of the... Carencistas.
Yes.
But of course, I mean, it would be very hard to prove anything like that.
Why would your husband say that?
Because he believed in the revolution.
And you say his family is not... No, they're not refugees.
They've been here for a long time.
Well, his family was from the little town of Guerrero.
Yes.
And his grandfather...
More or less around that time, I believe, that was when my husband lost his father.
And his mother, with all her children, moved to Zapata, to a ranch that my husband's grandfather had.
And his family name is Zapata.
Yes.
Is he a descendant of the Antonio Zapata?
No, no.
Not to my knowledge.
I really don't know.
He always makes a joke of it, and he says that he comes from...
Zapata, the revolutionist Emiliano Zapata.
That's a long way off.
He makes a big joke out of it.
I don't believe that he really knows whether, he says that there was some relation with Antonio Zapata.
Yes.
And the problem was because the name Zapata is not a very common name.
And so after that, we stayed here.
And I remember that when my father came back, of course my grandmother was elated over the fact that her son was back home.
But there was no working here.
I mean, we were left absolutely penniless.
And we couldn't stay with mother because her home was big.
An average size home for a couple, but not for four more people.
Let's say four more people.
Because it was my father, my grandmother, and five.
My aunt, my sister, and myself.
So we moved.
I can't even remember where.
Houses were very, very hard to find.
At first we lived in a small, small place that I can't even tell you.
The only thing that I remember is that my father said, you girls cannot go out and play with anyone here in this neighborhood.
Because I guess he felt like they were not our class, our kind.
But we grabbed whatever we could.
And surviving was actually the main thing.
And many other people, like the Longorias,
came, you know, .
I've heard the name.
All right.
They came and moved in with my aunt, who lives at a corner from us.
Because they, too, didn't have a house in which they were to move to.
Well, Loretta was really full of refugees at that time.
Yes, that was the trouble.
See, so you grabbed whatever you could.
Then we moved to another house, and it was half of the house.
We lived in half of the house, the other half of the house.
a friend of my daddy's read, he and his wife.
And it was like that for several years until we were able to, daddy was able to get back on his own two feet and we started school and that's about it.
Well what kind of work did your father eventually find?
Well at first he did anything.
I really don't know what he did, but he would do just anything.
But finally, that's when custom brokers started.
My husband is a custom broker, a forwarding agent.
That's what they're called now.
But we used to call them custom brokers, agente aduanal.
And my father worked with an agente aduanal.
He ran the office for Mr. Gonzalez.
And, of course, it was in his line of work because he had always been a custom man.
Had he spoken English before the Revolution?
No, he didn't speak a word of English.
Not a word.
He never knew any English.
He never did learn.
I never heard a word of English in my home.
Never.
Not a word.
So that made it even more difficult for him on this side.
Of course, Spanish here was the main language.

you would go to the stores and everybody knew what you were talking about so it wasn't as much of a handicap as it would have been someplace else now knowing English or vice versa knowing Spanish is a must we live in a bilingual absolutely bilingual Laredo is almost completely on both sides bilingual community it is a bilingual community really
And I don't remember of any, absolutely, I absolutely don't remember of any...
When I started school, I don't remember that I was...
The fact that I came from Mexico or that I was Mexican had anything to do with it.
Of course, most of my classmates were Mexican, of Mexican descent, maybe Americans, because we keep on thinking of Mexicans when we are really American.
I am an American in that I became an American citizen.
My husband still is a Mexican citizen.
He is.
Yes.
And when my grandmother passed away,
She was buried in Mexico.
When my father passed away, he was buried in Mexico.
My uncle passed away and his wife passed away.
They were buried in Mexico.
So they retained very strong emotional ties.
They were very, very strongly tied to.
And we still are.
We are.
Why did your father not return to Mexico after the revolution?
Because he was not allowed to go.
Well, things quieted down.
Yes, they quieted down.
But he was absolutely against everything that the revolutionists stood for.
And they, naturally, they would have
In the first place, he didn't want to go as long as it was in the hand of the new party.
And in the second place, there was a danger of his being imprisoned.
He was still identified with the idea.
Yes.
He was still identified, and not only that, he was still helping.
Yeah, Felix Diaz was still in Mexico, or off and on, up until 1919 or later, wasn't he?
I believe he was.
There was always the possibility of Diaz countering.
Well, Felix was the nephew.
Yes, those were my father's dreams.
And I remember that he used to cry, literally cry.
You could see his tears rolling down his cheeks when he stood and looked across.
into his country, or he would hear the bugles, because Laredo was a very quiet town.
So if the soldiers were, if for any reason you could hear the bugles, he would cry.
He longed to be in Mexico.
I don't remember, I don't know what year it was that he went back.
But we never returned.
We stayed here.
Because there was actually, there wasn't anything for him to do in Mexico.
What year did he die?
Daddy died in 1952.
The first year that I know, I remember in September of 1952.
So I remember that our oldest son had been, that was his first year in college when Daddy died.
He had just gone off to Missouri to Kemper Military School in Missouri when Daddy died.

and but he always and at the time by then he was living in mexico oh he did go back i remember i told you that he remarried yes he remarried now when was this yeah this is after you were grown yes well uh my little brother would be i think that daddy must have remarried in uh
Let me see, 52 and about 43.
And was his wife from here or from Mexico?
No, she was from Mexico.
From where in Mexico?
From a little small town between Monterey and Nuevo Laredo.
which is called, it's almost non-existent now.
Well, Sabina Sedalgo has existed.
No, yes, it's another little town.
Oh, there's a little ghost, there's a little almost ghost mining town down there.
All right, that's a lot.
Yeah, I know where it is.
That's where she was originally from.
And my father, even though he was, I mean, he was not, he was still considerably, he was old, but...
Not too old not to be able to bear children.
What year was he born?
Daddy?
I have to go back and think.
I really don't know.
Maybe.
Maybe.
No.
Well, how old was he when he died?
I don't remember.
No.
But it was about 1980.
More or less around 1980.
Well, then after he married, the second time he returned to Mexico.
Yes, and he had this child.
And he naturally, he adored him because he was, well, for one thing,
We two were married.
My sister and I were married.
And he loved my children very, very dearly.
I already had my two sons.
But my father's name was Gustavo, and they named my little brother Gustavo also.
We called him Tabito.
He was a very, very lovely child, and a beautiful child too, unfortunately.
Daddy passed away in 52, and unfortunately, Tabito
developed cancer of the lungs and died when he was 18 years old.
That's so unusual.
It just went like this, like fire.
And his mother, is she still alive?
Yes, his mother is still alive.
We don't see her very often because she's not in Abuelaredo most of the time.
There are times when she is.
Well, it was a very short-lived relationship.
Not that we were against daddy remarrying, because I think that it was wonderful that he didn't give us a stepmother when we were young.
So we realized that he needed a wife.
He needed someone to look after him, even though he has.
But it would have never been the same.
But he didn't live long enough to...
to see his little boy grow up.
In fact, my brother, my half-brother was much younger than my children because I have my oldest son is 37 and my second son will be 34 tomorrow.
My baby
is 27.
She's a girl.
She's married, too.
And my two brothers were already, my two boys were already born.
In fact, my daughter was born, Tabitha was born in March, and Mariangela came in November of that same year.
And Daddy would
I tell Tavito, these are your nephews.
They are your nephews.
You're their uncle.
And of course, it was very hard for my children to understand that Tavito was their uncle when they were older than he was.
I can see why.
Well, when your father moved back to Mexico, it was to Nuevo Laredo.
Yes.
Had he retired then, or did he?
No, he was still working.
He worked until the very last.
In fact, he was bookkeeper for...
for a big liquor store, Escamilla.
And he worked there until he died.
He died on this side.
By the time he went back to Mexico, how did he feel about the revolution and everything that had happened?
Well, he was bitter.
He was always bitter.
But he admitted, I mean, the fact that they had no chance.
that was past history and they would have to accept it as it was.
And he was friendly with the people, with the government people and everybody respected him and there was no animosity between them.
Of course he was one of the old timers and he had old timer friends who were living in Nuevo Laredo.
And so he actually made a comeback, so to speak.
Unfortunately, my grandmother sold her property.
She says, we'll never move back to Mexico.
I might as well sell it.
And my father was very much against it, but it was her own home.
Just the land, naturally, because the house was destroyed.
Right now it's very, very valuable, but it was her desire and there wasn't anything we could do.
This is not infrequent.
There's a very interesting story about
from some towns I studied that were disrupted by Paricutin volcano.
Yes.
And they moved and they sold.
Yeah.
And one man, he didn't even sell his land.
Of course, volcanic ash had fallen on it.
And it wasn't worth anything then.
But it's very good now.
What he did was tear his papers up.
He just tore them up and burned them and said, no more town, no more land, and left.
And they say he still cries about it.
He lives in California now.
He sits down.
Crying won't bring it back, though.
Not even selling it.
But this is not uncommon, apparently.
It's just a reaction to catastrophe, really.
I guess so.
I'll remember that, just in case.
But now, your mother's, or your father's family from Coahuila, what town were they from?
Candela.
Candela.
Yes.
Were they ranchers or ?
Yes, yes, and ranchers.
So I remember that my grandmother used to say that when they would travel from one, from Candela to some other place, she had many sisters, and they would all wear
sort of like porcelain that were made for that purpose with wide strips.
And those were filled with the gold coins.
Because I imagine they feared being attacked.
They raised a lot of sheep and goats.
And when my great grandfather would sail,
I guess, I don't know, I remember that one thing that my grandmother used to tell us.
Her name was Barreda.
B-A-R-R-E-D-A.
And she said, she used to tell us that actually her name was De La Barreda.
De La Barreda.
And there were two brothers who were given
Well royalties from Spain, one was his name was Ramon and the other one was Fructuoso and this Ramon was my great great grandfather.
Did he come directly from Spain?
Yes, directly from Spain and Fructuoso was lost.
They don't know whether the Indians
caught him or what.
They never did hear from him anymore.
So the only branch of the La Barredas was from this Ramon de la Barreda.
But then they dropped the De La and just called themselves Barreda.
It seems like I read somewhere that a lot of families dropped the De La during the war for Mexican independence or shortly afterwards.
Well, I imagine it could have been then that they did it.
But there were
rich people.
And my grandfather, Picasso, came from a small town, Ahualewas.
Ahualewas is in the state of Nuevo Len.
Now how did he, oh wait a minute, that's your father, how did he meet your mother?
My father, or you're talking about my grandfather,
My grandfather was from Ahualewas.
Oh, your grandfather.
How did he meet your grandmother?
Oh, that I don't know.
She never told you that?
I wish she would have told me.
I wish.
She would have been interested.
And the only aunt we had living, who had a tremendous memory, my daddy's older sister, older than himself, she remembered, she knew everything, but we never took
We never stopped to ask her those little things that mean so much in life.
In fact, she gave me this set.
It was hers, and she told me, you keep it, you take it.
And so I treasure it most highly, and I treasure that picture, too.
Because that picture, to me, is part of my childhood.
Wherever I went, the first thing that my grandmother would sit doing was that the picture was hung in a place
where it's very heavy, where it wouldn't break or fall or something.
Did your aunt also come to the United States, your father's older sister?
Yes.
The one I'm talking about?
No, no.
She lived in Nuevo Laredo.
Her husband also came from Candela.
And they came, I imagine, during the revolution, they came to Nuevo Laredo.
I really don't know when.
And they only had one daughter, and she still lives.
She's still living, and she has a nice home on Aveo Avenue, but she lives by herself.
And she's a very strange person.
I mean, she's had a hard life in that she's by herself.
Economically, she doesn't like anything.
But she lives a very, very sad life, and no matter
We asked her to come over and spend some days with us.
Oh no, she would never think of leaving her home.
And so as a result, her life is rather sad.
She reads a lot.
And she's up to everything.
But her mother had a tremendous memory, I'm telling you.
This is actually your grandmother's sister you're talking about.
No, I'm talking about my father's sister.
Your father's sister.
His oldest sister.
I didn't know any of my grandmother's sisters.
None of them.
This is your father's oldest sister.
I did know my grandmother's brother, Ramon.
Named after his father, Ramon de la Valeria.
lived in Monterey, at least his daughters still live in Monterey.
So, and then on my mother's side, my grandfather also worked, he was a custom man also, and his name was Barrera.
B-A-R-R-E-R-A.
Well, that's very similar.
Very similar, except for the D. So I'm Caso on my father's side, Barrera on my mother's side.
And then Barrera, my third name, and then Martinez.
Now, after you came here, you went to school.
Oh, yes.
How long did you go to school?
Well, I graduated from high school, and then...
I started teaching without, with nothing but a teacher's certificate that you were able to obtain by taking a Jillian.
I went to summer school in San Marcos and I took what was required in order to obtain a teaching certificate.
And we took exams.
every single course that we had taken during our 12 years of school.
Everything, just everything.
And I got my certificate, and I felt like I was safe.
I came home with my certificate, ready to teach.
A requirement to teach was you had to be an American citizen.
My father said no.
You are a Mexican, and I want you to remain a Mexican.

But later on, he came in without my really, I didn't exactly beg him, but I guess I must have made him realize that it was a shame that I could help, and yet I was unable to because of his pride to remain always a Mexican citizen.
We lived here.
This was a country that had given us a home.
So when I got my citizenship papers, I started teaching, as I told you.
And I taught for just for 30 years.
For 30 years?
Just 30 years?
Just 30 years.
But in the meantime, of course, I couldn't keep on teaching with that little old certificate.
they offered extension courses from A&I.
And we started, all of us, I mean all of the young teachers in those days, we started taking courses because in the first place, my father wouldn't dream of my going to school.
Away from home.
I went to Austin for six weeks to the University of Texas
But daddy took me and we stayed in what was called Newman Hole, run by nuns.
But father thought that being run by nuns, we would be in at 8 o'clock and that we would be supervised by nuns.
He didn't realize that we were free to do whatever we wanted to.
Of course, I mean, I knew better and I knew exactly how to behave.
thanks to, I'm proud to say that he instilled that in us.
Then, later on, I kept on taking courses here in Laredo.
And then, since Kingsville was not far, I used to take courses by going on Saturdays, and by attending school during the summer months.
And I stayed in the city court at home, which was run by the Sisters of Mercy.
So the only way that Daddy would have consented to my going off to school for a whole one or two years would have been if I would have been in a convict with high walls.
Broken glass on top?
Yes, yes, yes.
Bless his heart.
Well, how many years did you teach before you got married?
About four.
Four years.
And what did you teach?
I always taught the elementary grades.
My last years, I was head teacher.
Then, instead of being assistant principal, you were a head teacher.
And Mrs. Smith, I didn't teach in this particular school across the street.
I taught in another one that's...
Oh, well, more or less going towards Zapata.
What's called now Dykes School, but it was Montrose.
And I was head teacher there for several years.
And then I was made, we had a new principal, Mr. Barrow.
And I was made assistant principal.
And then Mr. Barrow passed away and I was made principal.
So I was a principal for Montrose School for several years.
And I retired when I was not
Not old, I mean, not old enough to get all the benefits.
But I thought, well, I've helped my husband enough, and I want to be home and enjoy life.
And they used to say, but look, now that you're a principal, you're going to retire.
Yes, I made up my mind.
I'm going to retire, and that's it.
Would you believe that my first retirement check was $79?
I'm still getting it because they're different.
You can choose one, two, or three, and I can't remember what number.
I think one, you get the whole bulk.
Number two is something else.
I chose the third, whatever you call it.
And it has been raised.
Now I get $129.
If you'd taught until you were 65 or something.
Until I was 60.
If I would have taught until I was 60, I would have made a much, much, much higher salary.
I mean, I would have received a much higher retirement check.
But I don't regret it.
I really don't.
Because in the first place, my husband doesn't need it.
And I don't feel like I have accomplished more by being home.
than by teaching.
I enjoyed my years of teaching.
I really did.
And I'm proud to say that my children still remember me.
Children's mothers still remember me, the teachers that were with me when I was a principal.
Whenever they see me, they say, we'll never have another principal like you, and things like that, which do make you feel proud of the fact that you retired before you got too cranky.
Well, did you stop teaching at all when you were having your children?
Except, let me see.
When Renato Jr. was born, I didn't teach the first semester because he was born in November.
This was your oldest son.
My oldest son.
Then when Javier was born, I taught all the year, the whole year.
And then when my baby was born, my young one was born, I had two miscarriages during that time.
And so the doctor and my husband said, no, you're not going to teach.
But I felt like I wanted to teach because I had put so many years that I wanted to get the benefits that were due to me.
That's the reason I taught.
I've always put it this way.
At first,
I taught because I had to and because I liked it.
First because I liked it and then because I had to.
Then I taught because my husband needed, I wanted to help him so that we would really be able to get to where we are now.
But the last years that I taught, I taught because I considered that I should.
I was entitled to a little benefit for all the years that I had put into the profession.

And my husband used to say every time, he said, please, honey, I don't want you to come home and be tearful because this little boy didn't have shoes and the other child needed a haircut and things like that.
I said, now look.
If I sell buttons and lace and thread, in other words, if I go to work as a clerk, then I promise you that I will never come home talking about my work.
But as long as it's children that I'm dealing with, I'm going to do it with all my heart.
And I'm going to give them everything that I can.
There's really no other way.

Otherwise, you're not a teacher.
No, you have to be calling.
You have to have a calling for it.
I baptized children that were 9 and 10 years old, because they had never been baptized.

because the mother had made a promise that if he got well, they would let his hair grow, which now would be very, very popular.

And they would come to me, the mothers would come to me, and my husband didn't bring any money.
They cut off the gas and they cut off the water.
And I remember a butcher at ATV one time I went and I helped the family as I could.
And he told me, Ms. Zapata, I want to ask a favor of you.
I don't want you to interfere with my family.
I said, oh, no.
Never will I interfere with your family.
But if your family, if your children are hungry, I am going to interfere.
